body:
I don't think matlab code exists for 3D.

What does exist, though, is my pycuda + skcuda code for 3D, and yes we should check against that.

As for 1D, yeah there are a selection of implementation to compare against also, and that is a good idea.

The procedure for this: Use the reference code to transform a few reference images, save everything to disk, commit that to the repo.
Ok. Will start comparing the 1D outputs.

issue.title: [BUG] Scattering3D chemistry example currently yields too high MAE error

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body: This needs to be addressed or at least understood before release.

body:
Okay, I'm not willing to be annoying, but those unit tests are mad important. If you can provide me one in the next 48h, I could significantly PR the code. I can't do it myself because I need a ground truth(which I could do for 2d for which i'm familiar)

Thanks :) !!!!!

For the 3D part, there is the possibility of taking 3-5 molecules from qm7, and transforming them with the old code to have a comparison. Probably random sparse dots transformed or a little cube would also do the trick.

For full reproduction, I guess but the signal and the filter bank should be provided. The issue is that for the chemistry project we had to be very careful with sampling limits and optimize in two directions. Louis and Georgios did a lot of that. If neither of them can dig this out, I'll go and look, but it will probably take me a while.
@eickenberg just provide any groundtruth. In my case, I took standard filters with a random noise signal. This was enough until now to discover bugs(I discovered a bug in the MATLAB version actually)

@gexarcha @louity I am trying to run https://bitbucket.org/dataens/playground/src/master/n_body_scattering_on_qm7.py in order to save out, for 5 molecules:

- scattering coefficients
- wavelets
- maybe the first order moduli

I get the following error:

```
     12 aug_qm7.R = augment(qm7.R)
     13 
---> 14 positions, properties = scattering_utilities.convert_qm7_to_positions_and_properties_arrays(qm7)
     15 positions = positions[:QM7_BATCH_SIZE]
     16 properties = properties[:QM7_BATCH_SIZE]

AttributeError: module 'n_body_scattering.scattering_utilities' has no attribute 'convert_qm7_to_positions_and_properties_arrays'

```

And I can't find that function in the `n_body_scattering` repo. Could one of you check whether this runs out of the box on your machines, and then just dump out the coefficients, so that we can create tests for outputs and filters?

Ok. So I've been comparing the MATLAB and Python codes. They do not produce the same output. Part of it seems to be different filter banks, but it also looks like the Python version does the actual calculation in a different way (different padding and subsampling behavior, different criteria for selecting second-order coefficients, etc). So it is not possible to use the MATLAB output as a reference as things stand right now.

A few options are available to us:
- Hack the MATLAB version so that its behavior more closely mimics the Python version (this seems silly).
- Rework the Python version to more closely mimic the MATLAB version (this would take quite some time, but might be a good idea in the long term).
- Save the output from the Python version and use that for our unit tests.

I would vote for the third option. Once we have things stabilized, we can look at adapting filter banks, etc, to more closely match the MATLAB version, if that's desirable.

Yes, I see how that kind of divergence can happen. Similar things are going on with the 3D code, though the gap is smaller. Would you say that the matlab code has something "canonical" to it and in the future the 1D implementation should reflect that, or is it "just a design choice" and OK as is?

> Save the output from the Python version and use that for our unit tests

Which Python version are you referring to here?
I agree: This third option seems to be the way to go here.

> For the 3D part, there is the possibility of taking 3-5 molecules from qm7, and transforming them with the old code to have a comparison. Probably random sparse dots transformed or a little cube would also do the trick.
> 
> For full reproduction, I guess but the signal and the filter bank should be provided. The issue is that for the chemistry project we had to be very careful with sampling limits and optimize in two directions. Louis and Georgios did a lot of that. If neither of them can dig this out, I'll go and look, but it will probably take me a while.

It's unlikely for that to happen. I think too many things changed from the two codes (ordering of coefficients, size of gaussians, location of molecules etc.) and bugs could be there in the old code too. The way we go about it is making clean code that reproduces the results of the old code or improving on them.

By the Python version I mean @AndreuxMath's code that's in the repo. As for "canonical", I don't think so. Using slightly different filters, etc., shouldn't really affect performance too much. On the other hand, the MATLAB code has already been quite optimized and we know it gets good performance on several tasks. It might be helpful to have it as a "soft reference" and make sure we reproduce that performance on TIMIT, GTZAN, etc.

> I think too many things changed from the two codes (ordering of coefficients, size of gaussians, location of molecules etc.)

*location of molecules:* This is why I propose to save out the densities
 *ordering of coefficients:* There are two basic ways of doing this and a way to map between them

> bugs could be there in the old code too

maybe so, but nevertheless it remains the reference that got a decent error level on QM predictions.

So the way I thought this could be done is to:

- Get densities generated by the old code
- Get filters generated by the old code
- Use both of these in the old code and the new code to obtain
    1. Scattering integrals
    2. First-layer wavelet moduli

That should be possible, and give enough safety to compare.

I was on my way to doing that but hit some form of refactoring "bug" which made one function disappear (cf above stack trace). That's why I was wondering whether you could help out.

> clean code that reproduces the results of the old code or improving on them

That would be great -- one way I see of getting there is doing the above. But yeah, this is the goal. If we attain it by a different procedure, I'll be happy, too :)

Ok. So for 1D, I will make a simple test that verifies against the saved output of the current code for some test output. That way we can start refactoring. We'll look into harmonizing with the MATLAB code later.
@louity very important you do this from your working version!
